fields.trailText: Rolling report: Join Tanya Aldred for live coverage of the action around the grounds in the County Championship
fields.body:
3.57pm BST

Sam Northeast has gone at Taunton for a hard-working 67 as Tom Abell makes a crucial breakthrough. Hampshire continue to edge forward, just 206 behind.

3.49pm BST

Glamorgan need 188 to win!

They‚Äôve taken tea at Sophia Gardens, with the promise of an entertaining run-chase to toast day. Invaluable nurdling from Saqib Mahmood and Danny Lamb at the end. Neser 4-53, two each for Lamb and Douthwaite.

3.45pm BST

Play abandoned at Canterbury for the day!

Northants knew what they were up to yesterday, banging out four bonus points while the sun shone.

3.43pm BST

Pennington back in the wickets at New Road, with numbers 7 and 9. Durham lead by 219.

3.36pm BST

Warwickshire are a-crumbling in their second innings. Currently 5-2 after four overs, with Pieter Malan and Will Rhodes‚Äôs afternoon closed. The lead 159.

3.24pm BST

Teenage kicks: Yorkshire 130-2.

3.20pm BST

Follow on NOT enforced by Warwickshire, who bat again with a first-innings lead of 153.

Meanwhile Sam Northeast has tacked together a valuable fifty at Taunton, paying what I think they described as a ‚Äúholding-role‚Äù in football. Hampshire 124-5.

3.15pm BST

A hundred for David Bedingham!

Not many centuries this round (Brown, Harris and Bedingham, I think), but another beauty from Bedingham who is providing welcome heft to the Durham middle order. The lead over Worcestershire now 202.

3.12pm BST

Derbyshire all out 121!

The last wicket stand added a sixth of the runs after a collapse of 8-45. Norwell 4-24, Miles 5-30. Will they follow on? We wait....

2.59pm BST

Still no play at Kent, Chelmsford or Lord‚Äôs.

For balance, the top ten leading wicket-takers this season:

Rushworth (Durham) 37

Coverton (Somerset) 36

Fletcher (Notts) 36

Abbott (Hants) 34

Harmer (Esses) 34

Higgins (Gloucs) 33

Sam Cook (Essex) 32

Carse (Durham) 32

Olly Robinson (Sussex) 29

Bamber (Middx) 28

[Broad has 19 from four games, Wood 10 from three games, Anderson 3 in two games but one innings]

2.51pm BST

Hampshire 110-5, as James Hildreth at slip says thank you to a softly-dropping plum from Liam Dawson.

2.47pm BST

Ah! Thank you Gary.

2.38pm BST

O youth! The strength of it, the faith of it, the imagination of it! Ibrahim strikes with ball. Kohler-Cadmore lbw for 25. Yorkshire 83-1.

2.35pm BST

Like a moonlit shadow, Derbyshire dance where Lancashire tread. From 76-2 to 98-7. Craig Miles 4-26, Norwell 2-20.

2.33pm BST

A breakthrough at Taunton! James Vince is caught at backward point after an uncharacteristically patient 29. Hampshire 100-4.

I‚Äôve learnt that Dan Ibrahim is now the youngest player to make fifty on debut in the Championship. The previous record was held by Bilal Shafayat - who in my mind played a Test for England, but my mind is wrong. Cricinfo confirms U19 England caps and a glorious season in 2005 when he made 1000 runs for Notts.

2.18pm BST

Gosh Lancashire really are, um, getting a move on. They‚Äôve now lost 5-11, with Vilas and Bailey joining the heavy pavilion-trudge. Three for Neser, one for Douthwaite and a run out. Currently, 125-8, a lead of 148.

2.11pm BST

That run-out :

And a reminder of the owner of that mellifluous welsh voice: Eddie Bevan of course. Thank you!

Updated at 2.15pm BST

2.09pm BST

Hopes of a tea-start at Lord‚Äôs

2.07pm BST

Glamorgan‚Äôs statement on welcoming fans back to Sophia Gardens:

We welcome today‚Äôs announcement from the Welsh Government of a return of spectators to watch live events in Wales this summer.

The two metre social distancing regulation will restrict our capacity to a maximum of 2,892 and we will continue to work closely with key partners including the Welsh Government, Public Health Wales, and Cardiff City Council on a safe return of fans to Sophia Gardens.

We have prepared and submitted proposals for a phased return of fans to Sophia Gardens from next week and look forward to providing more information as soon as the necessary approvals have been confirmed.

Once again, we would like to thank our members, fans and partners for their patience and look forward to welcoming supporters back to Sophia Gardens in greater numbers.

2.05pm BST

Gary Naylor confirms a Lancs-up in progress.

Here‚Äôs the first of the three to fall since lunch:

2.02pm BST

A post-lunch trickle: Madsen and McDermot shot out by Miles (3-23) at Derby: 82-4, 192 behind Warwicks. Chris Wright picked off by Hammond at the run-fest at Grace Road, Leicestershire 439-8. Oh dear, and Lancashire have lost 3-4 at Sophia Gardens: Bohannon, Livingstone, and Wood run-out without facing a ball. Lancs 113-6.

1.52pm BST

Just watered the garden for the first-time in a while, cautiously optimistic about the soft-fruit season. Talking of which... ah, no-one has collapsed in the ten minutes since lunch.

1.06pm BST

Lunchtime scores

Group one

Derby: Derbyshire 61-2 v Warwicks 274

Chelmsford: Essex v Notts 248-6 no play before lunch

Worcester: Worcester 131 all out v Durham 252-4

Group two

Grace Road: Leicestershire 436-7 v Gloucestershire

Taunton: Somerset 360 all out v Hampshire 67-3

Group three

Sophia Gardens: Glamorgan 150 all out v Lancashire 173 and 88-3

Canterbury: Kent v Northamptonshire 362-5 no play before lunch

Headingley: Yorkshire 26-0 v Sussex 313 all out

12.59pm BST

Godleman straggles back to the Derby pavilion after being caught behind for 32. Derby 61-2 shortly before lunch. At Headingley, the Yorkshire openers are still whole, if with an uneven scorecard. Kohler Cadmore one not out; Lyth 16 not out including a morning heave-ho for six! Yorks 22-0.

12.53pm BST

David Bedingham is the only man with more than 700 runs this season - and still he bats. Currently 65 not out at New Road as Durham sail into a sobering lead: 241-4, a lead of 112 over Worcestershire.

12.44pm BST

Al Davies and Luke Wells steaming along at Sophia Gardens, but Keaton Jennings‚Äô more circumspect innings is over. Lbw to Weighell for 12. A bump down to earth in this game after his classy hundred last week. Lancashire 72- hang on, they‚Äôre now 72-2. Wells bowled for 26 by Douthwaite.

12.39pm BST

Sussex all out 313! Now Yorkshire get a go. Will it be the Yorkshire of the first innings of the Roses match -159 all out - or the Yorkshire who battled to so-close to the bitter end in the second innings?

12.34pm BST

This is just showing off!

12.32pm BST

Gloucestershire having a spell in the doldrums. Leicester now 411-7, with a helpful 47 extras.

And, in case this appeals:

12.17pm BST

No dream debut for Ibrahim, but dreamy enough. Well played, young pup. Sussex 310-8.

12.15pm BST

Lunch will be taken at 1pm at Lord‚Äôs, where the rain continues to pour.

Hampshire, meanwhile, are in trouble: 31-3 after de Lange removes Steel and Alsop in one over. Holland already gone, caught VDM off Davey.

12.11pm BST

Just perusing the Championship averages as if it was 1985 and they were taking up a whole page in the Telegraph.

The highest England players are 7th placed Ollie Pope (78.83) and 8th placed Rory Burns (53.73)

Top ten:

Van der Merwe, Somerset

Bedingham, Durham

Carlson, Glamorgan

RS Patel, Surrey

MS Harris, Leicestershire

Vasconcelos, Northants

Pope, Surrey

Burns, Surrey

MAH Hammond, Gloucestershire

Abell, Somerset

Updated at 12.12pm BST

11.51am BST

Derbyshire have lost their first wicket, 8-1, but Durham billow onwards, Beingham and Jones steadfast in a partnership of fifty. Their lead over Worcestershire an almost commanding 53, with six wickets remaining.

11.45am BST

The lovely voice of the Glamorgan commentator is lulling me into a trance, but can report that at Derby Warwickshire are all out for 274, an impressive effort by Derby, who are already batting and 7-0.

There will be an inspection at Canterbury at 12.20.

11.34am BST

Fifty for Dan Ibrahim!

How‚Äôs that on debut?! Seven fours and as calm as a tarn on an early spring morning.

11.30am BST

Ticket offer!!!

Brian Withington has very kindly offered two free tickets for England v New Zealand at Edgbaston next Friday June 11th to a lucky BTL-er. If you are interested, please email me at tanya.aldred.freelance@theguardian.com and I can put the two of you in touch. There is a Covid consent form that should be completed ASAP and a lateral flow test requirement as condition of entry.

Updated at 11.31am BST

11.23am BST

An email wafts in with the jasmine. It‚Äôs from Finbar Anslow:

‚ÄúHello Tanya,

Just wanted to let you know how wonderful my yesterday was. Cutting the grass and only stopping to check scores when I found a bit of shade (memo, plant more trees) So lovely to watch Lewis Gregory score a ton and the Marchant of menace in action. However even in paradisiacal Piedmont the occasional question flutters through one‚Äôs thoughtless contemplation........Why is Reina del Cid‚Äôs Harvest moon so damned good?Was Edward Snowden right? Is there a file on each and every one of us, just awaiting a moment of fame for our sins to be exposed.Should Somerset send their bowlers in to open the batting?
Any enlightenment gratefully received

11.18am BST

At Headingley, Ben Coad grabs Sussex‚Äôs main man, centurion Ben Brown. Sussex 275-6 with 16-year -old Ibrahim not out 43. He‚Äôs ‚Äúdoing a Conway.‚Äù

11.16am BST

Glamorgan all out 150!

Lancashire not hanging around. This could be all over today at the Gardens. Jennings and Davies march back out, Davies is off the mark with four and Lancashire are 6-0, with a first-innings lead of 23.

11.12am BST

And Ali‚Äôs nice report on Conway, Wood, Robinson, Root and co

Related: Rory Burns leads England revival after Devon Conway‚Äôs 200 for New Zealand

And Simon Burnton on the fallout from the Robinson affair.

Related: ECB to punish Ollie Robinson for racist and sexist tweets

11.08am BST

We‚Äôre rolling! Except at Canterbury, Chelmsford and Lord‚Äôs where the rain doth spout and spoil things.

Some fabulous reading from the Test. I thought this was brilliant on Ollie Robinson by Andy Bull.

Related: Ollie Robinson tries to block out the noise and get on with England job | Andy Bull

10.39am BST

Thursday's round-up

On a morning of cloud cover so heavy that the Headingley floodlights were switched on, and 2,056 souls planted their behinds around the ground for the first time for a men‚Äôs county game since 2019, Yorkshire chose to bowl.

With Sussex 68 for four just after lunch, it seemed a good decision. By stumps, less so, thanks to a smashing unbeaten 126 from Ben Brown, 40 from Aaron Thomason and a cameo of 37 from 16-year-old Danial Ibrahim.

Brown played with nimble feet and hands, running swiftly between the wickets and driving with panache, picking the gaps ably, like a pick-happy man with an orange pith obsession. Ibrahim was sighingly calm, straight drive here, flick there, making the most of late-afternoon Yorkshire bowling with the new ball that touched on the wayward.

Northamptonshire, the gluttons, bolted down four batting points before the close in a riotous day‚Äôs batting against Kent. Ricardo Vasconcelos and Emilio Gay put on 135 for the first wicket, before Gay, who made his maiden first-class century, and Luke Procter added 100 for the second. Darren Stevens, aged 45, picked up a couple of wickets with the second new ball to lead a mini-revival at the close.

There were two catches for Kent‚Äôs wicketkeeper Ollie Robinson, who received an apology from Kent Online, who had mistakenly pictured him in Wednesday‚Äôs story about the other Ollie Robinson.

Lancashire were squirrelled out by Glamorgan for 173 after a succession of batsmen got in, but then got out again, without adding greatly to the score. Tom Bailey scored a quickfire 31 to raise spirits, before picking up three wickets, as did Sajid Mahmood, as Glamorgan collapsed to 150 for nine.

Somerset unveiled their usual back-to-front batting style against Hampshire, reeling at 43 for five, laughing at stumps, 360 all out. Keith Barker grabbed six for 72, picking off the Somerset top order ‚Äì none who passed double figures apart from Steven Davies. The rearguard started with 45 from Tom Banton, and was bolstered by an eighth wicket stand of 171 between Lewis Gregory (107) and Roelof van der Merwe (88).

Marcus Harris plundered 148, his second century in succession, put Leicestershire in a happy position against Gloucestershire. They ended the day at 357 for five.

Worcestershire crumbled for 131 at New Road as Brydon Carse and Matty Potts snaffled four wickets each. Durham ended the day leading by nine with six wickets in hand, bolstered by 52 from Alex Lees.

Fifties from Lyndon James, Steven Mullaney and Joe Clarke, who restarted his innings after retiring hurt, inched Nottinghamshire on to the front foot against Essex. Peter Siddle finished with three for 76.

Sam Hain (77) and Michael Burgess (71) kept Warwickshire afloat on a muggy day at Derbyshire. Sam Conners had the top order in a pickle, taking the first four wickets, before the middle-order solidified to see them towards 272 for nine at stumps.

10.38am BST

Scores on the doors

Group one

Derby: Derbyshire v Warwicks 272-9

Chelmsford: Essex v Notts 248-6

Worcester: Worcester 131 all out v Durham 140-4

Group two

Grace Road: Leicestershire 357-5 v Gloucestershire

Taunton: Somerset 360 all out v Hampshire

Group three

Sophia Gardens: Glamorgan 150-9 v Lancashire 173 all out

Canterbury: Kent v Northamptonshire 362-5

Headingley: Yorkshire v Sussex 267-5

10.38am BST

Preamble

Good morning! June has pulled on her best summer dress, the long-tailed tits are flitting in the neighbour‚Äôs garden and the day has been marred only by an accident with the caftiere. A smorgasbord of great cricket in store, hopefully not marred too much by the weather, though it is raining in Canterbury.

Updated at 10.39am BST

fields.trailText: Rolling report: Serena Williams, Victoria Azarenka, Alexander Zverev and Daniil Medvedev are all in action. Join Luke McLaughlin
fields.body:
3.57pm BST

Opelka holds for 5-2. Williams and Collins, meanwhile, are with serve at 3-3 in the first.

3.55pm BST

Medvedev leads Opelka 5-1, closing on a two-set lead in under an hour. Opelka booms down a couple of big serves as he tries to stay in the second set.

Updated at 3.57pm BST

3.55pm BST

Giron hits back against Garin on Court 7 and takes the second set 7-5. Garin won the first 6-1.

3.52pm BST

Out on Court 14, another women‚Äôs singles match has just got under way: Sorana Cirstea (ranked 54) v Daria Kasatkina (ranked 37).

3.50pm BST

Williams and Collins are locked at 2-2 in the first on Court Philippe-Chatrier.

Updated at 3.50pm BST

3.47pm BST

Medvedev breezes to a 3-0 lead in the second set against the man-mountain Opelka.

Updated at 3.47pm BST

3.45pm BST

Medvedev is outclassing Opelka, he‚Äôs 2-0 up in the second set, having taken the first 6-4.

Both have started the match well, both striking the ball sweetly, and looking pretty evenly matched in the rallies. Pavlyuchenkova has just walked off court for a medical timeout. It‚Äôs with serve in the Azarenka v Keys match, at 2-1 to Keys, although it‚Äôs 30-30 on Azarenka‚Äôs serve now. In the battle of the Elenas, Rybakina has knocked out Vesnina, 6-1, 6-4. Sabalenka takes the second set, 6-2. Pavlyuchenkova simply couldn‚Äôt live with her opponent‚Äôs power and precision during that set. Sabalenka lacked precision in the first set, but has certainly found her range now, and there is going to be plenty of work to do for Pavlyuchenkova now. This is great to watch from Sabalenka, unless you are Pavlyuchenkova‚Äôs coach. Seemingly effortlessly she goes to 0-30 with a pass and a cleanly returned winner. And now to 0-40, three set points. The quality of Sabalenka‚Äôs hitting is looking more and more ominous for Pavlyuchenkova now. Sabalenka holds for 5-2, peppering her opponent with powerful groundstrokes, including one superb clean winner on her forehand side. Picturesque. An astonishingly good double-handed backhand return, which almost kisses the line right in the corner, creates two break points for Sabalenka. Pavlyuchenkova did not have a hope of getting close to that one. Sabalenka converts the first break point, and leads 4-2. She doesn‚Äôt over-celebrate, either, but looks quietly satisfied that her power hitting is starting to tell on the scoreboard. A comfortable Sabalenka hold for 3-2 in the second set. Meanwhile, Victoria Azarenka (15) and Madison Keys (23) are about to begin their third-round match on Court Philippe-Chatrier. Pavlyuchenkova, who is certainly looking the more consistent player, holds for 2-2. Sabalenka‚Äôs power is unstoppable when she gets it right, and she it not hesitating to attack, but she is also making too many errors in comparison with her opponent at the moment. Sabalenka puts away a forehand volley efficiently and holds comfortably for 2-1. Sabalenka has started this second set with renewed focus and is hitting the ball with serious authority compared to the second half of that first set. She goes on the attack to try and save a game point at 40-30, but sends a forehand wide, and it‚Äôs 1-1. Sabalenka holds serve impressively to open the second set, winning the first point with a cute drop-shot, and the second with another booming groundstroke to the baseline. Rybakina and Vesnina are now 2-2 in the second set, after Rybakina took the first 6-1. Over on Court 7, Katerina Siniakova took her first set against Tamara Zidansek 6-0, but Zidansek now leads 3-2 in the second. Pavlyuchenkova moves in behind a first serve and volleys decisively to take the first set, 6-4. It was very much a set of two halves, with Sabalenka sprinting out of the blocks and into a 3-0 lead. But a catalogue of errors by the Belarusian handed the initiative to Pavlyuchenkova, who won five straight games and sealed the set comfortably in the end. Unforced errors all over the place from Sabalenka. She dumps the first return of the game into the net, then sends a backhand long to gift Pavlyuchenkova a 30-0 advantage. Sabalenka holds, sealing the game with a big serve that was called out by a line judge. The umps leaves his seat to take a look at the mark, and rules it good. However, the Russian Pavlyuchenkova will now serve for the first set, at 5-4. A smart serve-volley from Pavlyuchenkova sees her save the break point, and she then takes the game for 5-3 in the first set. Sabalenka is clearly a bit frustrated with her game, and is occasionally venting her anger by winding up a huge forehand, or an unreasonably powerful second serve. Pavlyuchenkova attempts a delicate drop-volley which would put her 40-0 up on her serve, but places it fractionally wide. Sabalenka forces it to 30-30, and then absolutely destroys a brilliantly powerful forehand down the line for a break point. Much more like it from the Russian. Tennis - bloody hell! Pavlyuchenkova has now won four straight games and leads 4-3 in the first set. This one could get interesting. It‚Äôs 3-3 and all square in the first set between Pavlyuchenkova and Sabalenka. Sabalenka finds a couple of break points now, but the 29-year-old Pavlyuchenkova does well to bring it back to deuce in this sixth game of the first set. Our Eurosport commentator informs us that this is the 14th time Pavlyuchenkova has played at Roland Garros, which is quite a record. Sabalenka now saves a game point with a few massive groundstrokes that wear Pavlyuchenkova down with sheer force ... however, the Russian eventually finds a way. And now Pavlyuchenkova finds a break of her oppenents serve, and is right back in this first set at 3-2. Pavlyuchenkova is now on the board: it‚Äôs 3-1 in Sabalenka‚Äôs favour. Elsewhere, Elena Rybakina (21) now leads Elena Vesnina 5-0 in their first set. On Court Simonne Mathieu, Aryna Sabalenka (3) has raced into a 3-0 first-set lead against Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova (31). Sabalenka is the top-seeded player left in the women‚Äôs competition, following the withdrawals of Ash Barty and Naomi Osaka. The debate on Naomi Osaka‚Äôs withdrawal from this tournament rumbles on. Watch a video explainer, featuring the thoughts of our tennis reporter Tumaini Carayol, right here: Yesterday we saw Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Iga Swiatek, among others, progress safely to the third round at Roland Garros, while the women‚Äôs world No 1, Ash Barty, was forced to retire from her match against Magda Linette with a hip injury. There was also a notable flare-up over slow play between Federer and his opponent Marin Cilic. There was no shortage of action and drama on Thursday, so what will Friday bring? In the women‚Äôs singles, Victoria Azarenka faces Madison Keys from 11am, and Serena Williams will be on court at 3pm for a third-round match against compatriot Daniel Rose-Collins. In the men‚Äôs singles, Alexander Zverev is due on court at 11.15am to meet Laslo Dere of Hungary, and two hours after that, Daniil Medvedev will face off against the American Reilly Opelka. Those are just a few of the matches on today‚Äôs menu, which will no doubt be full of skill, intensity, super slow-motion replays, and frequent use of the towel. Let‚Äôs go!

fields.body:
3.57pm BST

‚ÄúAfternoon Adam.‚Äù Allo, Brian Withington. ‚ÄúAt Test Match level, a potentially useful sanction on the formerly amusing but now infamous Celebrappeal would be that it constitutes a deemed review of the compulsory not out decision. If reviews are already exhausted then it‚Äôs simply a no-ball. Sorted.‚Äù

Or just a bit of a re-jig to Law 42. Shouldn‚Äôt be too difficult.

Oh, there is some live international cricket on right now, I‚Äôm told!

3.54pm BST

Would it surprise you to learn that my entire inbox contains historical figures and where they might bat or bowl? Let‚Äôs do a handful more and I might move it on a bit after that.

‚ÄúIn their own very different ways,‚Äù writes Ewan Glenton, ‚Äúsurely Jack the Ripper, Lord Lucan and mathematician David Hilbert have all played themselves into contention as wicketkeeper over the years, having stumped so many people.‚Äù Very good.

‚ÄúI would absolutely insist on finding a space in the team for Sigmund Freud,‚Äù suggests Dawn Morgan. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd be a natural at slip.‚Äù

‚ÄúSurely Machiavelli as captain?‚Äù Kerrith Britland reckons. ‚ÄúAnd, of course, Caravaggio for some violent chin music.‚Äù

Peter Salmon wants Jacques Derrida. And he sends me a photo of the French philosopher playing the game as well - nice.

Peter Metcalfe, with his umpire‚Äôs hat on. ‚ÄúPope Gregory the First. With papal infallibility, there would be no need for any reviews.‚Äù

Last but not least, the great Gary Naylor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm surprised that the rather militaristic XI did not find room for Barnes Wallis, whose bouncers were more destructive than Harold Larwood‚Äôs.‚Äù

3.47pm BST

The short-history of hat-tricks. A note from from pal at Wisden Cricket Monthly Towers, Jim Wallace, who wrote the below piece. He‚Äôs writing to us from Lord‚Äôs. ‚ÄúIt looks wet. To get my Blackadder on - Wetter than Wet Wet Wet performing a cover of ‚Äòwaterfalls‚Äô on a wet weekend in Wetwang. For my money, Naseem Shah‚Äôs hat-trick is up there as one of the best, his age alone putting him in the conversation. Irfan Pathan‚Äôs first over effort and Mathew Hoggard‚Äôs Barbados blitzkrieg are also firm favorites.‚Äù

Related: A short history of cricket hat-tricks: from Sheffield's hills to Naseem Shah

3.40pm BST

This is, what we would call in my politics days, a killer fact.



3.39pm BST

No news is no news

Ian Ward confirms that a) it‚Äôs still raining and b) they need to be on by 6pm to get any play in today. They won‚Äôt need long to clean it up, that much I do know from having commentated all the county games at Lord‚Äôs this season. Half an hour of dry weather is enough.

‚ÄúSurely Sir Francis Bacon, Sir Water Raleigh, Victor Hugo should be in the team as they were all bowlers!‚Äù insists NC Benson. ‚ÄúAnd if you want variations surely Edward Elgar can‚Äôt be overlooked!‚Äù Wills Doug is here too: ‚ÄúThatcher‚Äôs a run out waiting to happen. (This lady‚Äôs not for turning).‚Äù And Tom Morgan has a few candidates. ‚ÄúGraham Greene fielding at third man? A Beatles tribute band in the covers? As captain, the great general Hannibal. If he could get elephants over the Alps, he could get a few more fiery old-ball overs out of a tired fast bowler.

Updated at 3.55pm BST

3.29pm BST

‚ÄúAfternoon Adam.‚Äù Allo, Elliot Brooks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure this has been litigated enough already, but surely just two tests isn‚Äôt enough for a New Zealand series? They‚Äôre always such great competition, and I always get a text from my mum at the start of each game that says: ‚ÄòIsn‚Äôt Kane Williamson lovely? A proper sportsman.‚Äô That‚Äôs real value, there.‚Äù

Okay, deep breath. Are we ready for my World Test Championship re-jig? Are you going to be kind in your emails when you disagree?

Two groups of six, for starters. It has to include all Test nations. And let‚Äôs accept that we‚Äôll find an elegant way to sort those groups out every two years - seedings from the previous cycle will do it.

What about the points? Here‚Äôs the controversial bit. For mine, only three-Test series to count in the WTC; no more two-Test business. All series (and matches) to therefore be worth the same.

Issue one: whaddabout the Ashes and other four/five Test series? In this model, only the first three would count in the WTC. My belief is that the Ashes/Border-Gavaskar is important enough that the final two Tests wouldn‚Äôt mean any less because the WTC bit is finished.

Issue two: the cost of putting on Tests - a big issue for many of the non-Big Three nations. A compromise. If they agree to play series of three instead of two, they can play those contests over four days.

Now, I dislike four-day Test cricket; I don‚Äôt want that to become the norm. But if this is the trade-off to get New Zealand playing Pakistan thrice at home, to set the global standard at three instead of two, then I think it is a worthy price to pay. Especially when those four-day affairs have been, so far, over 98-overs per day, rather than 90.

From there, the top team from each group makes the WTC Final. Alternatively, the top two, with a new round-robin to begin to determine the two teams to play in the Grand Final. Et voila!

3.17pm BST

‚ÄúAdam.‚Äù Andrew Benton. ‚ÄúAnd there I was, thinking a Celebrappeal was appealing in the style of a celebrity. That‚Äôd be much more fun, and an almost limitless supply of celebs to emulate / mock!‚Äù

It‚Äôs been great fun but it‚Äôs now a big part of the county game which, in turn, means it‚Äôll start to infect recreational cricket. No thanks.

Henry J. Heinz is Charles Sheldrick‚Äôs spinner in our Historical XI. ‚ÄúFor his numerous variations.‚Äù

3.14pm BST

‚ÄúGood afternoon Adam.‚Äù Hello, Sam Charlton. ‚ÄúWhilst not much of a problem at present at Lords, the glorious weather creates a unique issue I want to bring to your attention: face mask tan lines. An unfortunate soul whom I go out to events with as a nurse found this out the hard way. Obviously it is hilarious for everyone else, but not if you‚Äôre the victim.‚Äù

Only the hard-hitting issues during a rainy OBO! But it‚Äôs a good point. I once overdid it at the Aussie Open with sunglasses on with the burn line causing me all sorts of grief for about, oh, six months. Another time, falling asleep at the MCG with my shirt off (this day), nearly landed me in hospital. I deserved for it to land me in hospital.

3.10pm BST

The Historical Figures XI is popular. Stephen Holden wants Jesus Christ to feature in the middle order. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a big hitter. Apparently he cleared the temple.‚Äù Very good. Michael Robinson has Charlemagne in the mix. ‚ÄúAnd just in behind Caesar would be a nice place for Brutus.‚Äù A full XI from Mark Dawson? Alright, go on then:

Stonewall Jackson, La Pasionara, General Patton, Prince Rupert Erwin, Rommel (C, also handy as a fourth seamer), Marshal Ney, Florence Nightingale (keeper), Quintus Fabius, Oliver Cromwell, Marshall Zhukov Saladi.

Very... militaristic.

2.58pm BST

Hello, everyone. Like Daniel, I‚Äôm also about five miles from Lord‚Äôs and my assessment of the situation is much the same as his. But we‚Äôll make our own fun in the usual way, won‚Äôt we? I‚Äôve spent my morning writing about trying to stamp out Celebrappeals, because I‚Äôm a really cool guy like that. Coming from a place of love, of course - Broad fandom, one must be part of it. But still. That wasn‚Äôt good yesterday, from the England champion, nor Tim Southee later on.

Sorry to start negatively. Must be the rain. Here‚Äôs Nassem Shah‚Äôs hat-trick (featuring a Celebrappeal, wicket two) - what joyous cricket.

2.47pm BST

Right, that‚Äôs me done for the day. Here‚Äôs Adam Collins to ease you through the rest of the day, which will hopefully feature some klikkit ‚Äì email him on adam.collins.casual@theguardian.com.

2.46pm BST

‚ÄúI have managed to create a holy trinity of Steve Davis, Boiler Room and OBO,‚Äù says Patrick Duce. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôd have thought it? A one hour DJ set should get us through to the end of play?‚Äù

DJ Steve Davis is a bit techno for my taste ‚Äì what a succession of words that is ‚Äì but any port in a storm.

2.44pm BST

‚ÄúGreetings from sunny Lago Como,‚Äù brags Tom Morgan. ‚ÄúAlastair Campbell ‚Äì spin option, Mrs Tiggywinkle ‚Äì seam-stress, Coco Chanel ‚Äì number 5.‚Äù

Laugh!

2.42pm BST

‚ÄúXI of historical figures,‚Äù emails Alistair Leadbetter. ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs room in there for Gandhi, Einstein, Aristotle, and the fearsome duo of Martin Luther and Martin Luther King. This reminds me of when I used to play Owzat and had plenty of non-cricketing teams such as Rock Stars, Artists, Philosophers, Sunderland players, etc. I say ‚Äòused to‚Äô, but who am I kidding...? It helps pass a rainy day.‚Äù

Somewhere at my parents‚Äô house is an original set, and I can‚Äôt contest those suggestions, especially not the spin-twins of Einstein and Aristotle.

Updated at 2.43pm BST

2.41pm BST

‚ÄúDo you think the Black Caps were deliberately bowling on Burns‚Äô leg stump,‚Äù asks Ruth Purdue, ‚Äúor did they have their radar off? As he gets most of his runs on the leg side, it seemed curious.‚Äù

I‚Äôd guess the latter ‚Äì lefties get a load of deliveries in that area, and getting used or re-used to the slope probably exacerbates that.

2.39pm BST

It‚Äôs still raining just under five miles from Lord‚Äôs, so I imagine it‚Äôs still doing likewise at Lord‚Äôs. I‚Äôm still hopeful we‚Äôll get some play, but the forecast is not especially inspiring, and a total washout is undeniably on the agenda.

2.31pm BST

If we were compiling an XI of historical figures, who would be in it? Feel free to fill in the gaps, or drop those I‚Äôve picked.

1. Steve Davis

2. Alexander the Great

3. Julius Caesar

4.

5. Napoleon

6. God

7.

8.

9.

10.

11. Boudica (RF)

Updated at 2.34pm BST

2.19pm BST

Back to our earlier chat about pitches, another flat-track advantage is work for the spinners: on a 220 all-out green top, they‚Äôre not going to do much, but on a batting wicket they‚Äôll be as crucial as the first hour. I can see no flaw in this rationale whatsoever.

2.08pm BST

If it‚Äôs any consolation, is also raining in Paris ‚Äì but they‚Äôve got a roof.

Related: French Open 2021: Azarenka wins, Zverev and Serena Williams in action ‚Äì live!

1.57pm BST

Here we go, the ubiquitous prawns in Marie Rose their own separate course.

Updated at 1.58pm BST

1.53pm BST

Nothing to do with cricket, and yet everything to do with everything.

1.50pm BST

We‚Äôve got plenty play in the Champo, and Tanya Aldred has the latest ‚Äì check it out.

Related: Somerset v Hampshire, Glamorgan v Lancashire and more: county cricket ‚Äì live!

1.48pm BST

‚ÄúEnjoying the non cricket convo!‚Äù emails Mark Slater. ‚ÄúBecause I was otherwise occupied I am a bit late to the OBO, but I would like to voice my appreciation at the sharing of the Mysterons, the finest Hale and Pace appreciation turn ever!‚Äù

There aren‚Äôt many albums that so evoke a time, and I‚Äôm pleased to report that it‚Äôs aged beautifully ‚Äì I played it to my seven-year-old recently, and was greeted with none of the usual disparagement.

1.45pm BST

Just rereading the MCC colour explanation, is this the only context in which we talk of ‚Äúegg and bacon‚Äù rather than ‚Äúbacon and egg‚Äù? And is there a linguistic reason we describe paurs of objects in particular order, so never say ‚Äúchips and fish,‚Äù ‚Äúfork and knife‚Äù or ‚Äúblame and bang‚Äù?

Updated at 1.45pm BST

1.39pm BST

It's still raining

I‚Äôm afraid to say. I guess we‚Äôre 90 minutes away from play, minimum.

1.36pm BST

Hello again. ‚ÄúHow was it that the MCC chose the Catalan colours for their branding, way back in the mists of time?‚Äù wonders Andrew Benton. ‚ÄúEven the MCC logo looks like it‚Äôs a big C! Was there a tour to Barcelona in the 18xx‚Äôs that inspired them .... or did the Catalans like cricket and copy the MCC?‚Äù

The Lord‚Äôs website teaches as follows, but it doesn‚Äôt claim to be definitive:

‚ÄúThe original MCC colour of sky blue was replaced in Victorian times by the famous red and yellow. They are now recognised the world over (affectionately referred to as ‚Äòegg and bacon‚Äô).

MCC Museum houses a boundary flag dating from this period, which is the earliest known example of the red and yellow monogram, but it remains a mystery on why these colours were chosen ‚Äì though a number of explanations have been proposed.

The colours are similar to those used as racing colours by The Duke of Richmond who had strong ties with the Club in the early days of MCC. While it has also been suggested that the colours were borrowed from the wandering club I Zingari who were founded in 1845 and shared many members with the MCC.

However, common consensus leans to the Club taking on its colours as a personal thank you to William Nicholson who assisted in purchasing the freehold of Lord‚Äôs Ground. Nicholson, an MCC Member, was also the owner of the Nicholson‚Äôs Gin Company, the colours of which were red and yellow ‚Äì in what was perhaps an early example of corporate sponsorship.‚Äù

12.57pm BST

Right, I guess that‚Äôs lunch. I‚Äôm off to marinate some lamb ‚Äì see you in about 40, hopefully for some cricket.

12.56pm BST

There they are, the lads.

12.50pm BST

Goodness me. Sky are showing a doc about England‚Äôs hilarious trip to India in 1992-93; for the first Test, England picked four seamers and one spinner, while India picked one seamer and three spinners. Who to believe?

12.40pm BST

‚ÄúI‚Äôve expressed myself (and Tom) a little clumsily there,‚Äù returns Mike Daniels, ‚Äúbut the point he was making was that if you only play on flat wickets you won‚Äôt necessarily promote the mindset and techniques of taking wickets, you will, in the main, promote defensive bowling. You‚Äôre right that you need to take wickets to win a Test but you won‚Äôt necessarily develop the bowlers to think about taking wickets if you don‚Äôt put them into situations where the pressure is on them to take wickets, and there‚Äôs no better place to do that than in a situation where they are expected to, as opposed to hoping to. The bowler then has to develop the relevant techniques to do so in varied conditions.‚Äù

I see both sides, I really do, but it‚Äôs also the case that England have struggled to take 20 wickets in India and Australia and I‚Äôd guess that more practise on flat tracks is likely to be helpful.

12.33pm BST

On which point, I absolutely loved this ‚Äì sentiment and turn of phrase.

Please excuse my namedrop, but KP told me the same, and that if you were out or fielding, you waded in to the fullest possible extent. He also reserved particular praise the the prawns in Marie Rose sauce.

Updated at 12.34pm BST

12.31pm BST

Weather update: it‚Äôs still raining, so lunch will be taken as usual at 1pm meaning no play until 1.40pm at the earliest but realistically, it‚Äôll probably be later than that.

12.27pm BST

‚ÄúAt the risk of being ‚Äòthat guy‚Äô,‚Äù says Nick Ridgman, ‚ÄúI must insist that Detectorists is referred to by its proper name, sans rogue ‚ÄòThe‚Äô.‚Äù

Behold my ‚ÄúNetherlands‚Äù below!

12.25pm BST

‚ÄúStill trying to work out if Silverwood would have preferred a flat pitch or a lively one as a player,‚Äù muses Sean Clayton. ‚ÄúIf we believe Wikipedia, Bob Cottam claimed Silverwood was faster than Allan Donald (!) but I remember him as more of a swing and seam bowler than an outright paceman...‚Äù

I‚Äôm certain he‚Äôd have fancied a greentop ‚Äì and no, I‚Äôm not sure he was quite as quick as Ai Dee.

12.23pm BST

‚ÄúStealing a break to glance at the OBO in the rehearsal room (Le Wine Club with Anna Lou, opens Brighton Fringe June 19th since you ask),‚Äù begins Michael Keane. ‚ÄúShame about the weather but wondering if you have any updates on the ODI in Utrecht? Don‚Äôt know which site is best for scores so thought I‚Äôd email you. And much as I love Ireland, having the live stream on here while directing would probably be unprofessional...‚Äù

Netherlands are 123-8 off 40, so Ireland are pretty well-placed. Good luck with the play!

Updated at 12.23pm BST

12.19pm BST

‚ÄúFlatter pitches,‚Äù begins Mike Daniels. ‚ÄúTom Cartwright would say that producing flatter pitches doesn‚Äôt produce better bowlers except in the sense that they become better defensive bowlers. He ascribed to the view that pitches with something in them made for better bowlers as it put the pressure on the bowlers to deliver wickets and develop an attacking mindset rather than a defensive one. The good bowlers will find a way to take wickets on most surfaces if that‚Äôs the way that they set out to achieve.‚Äù

That‚Äôs a really interesting angle ‚Äì so much of sport, and life, is played in the mind. I‚Äôm not sure I can buy it though, because you can‚Äôt win a Test bowling defensively on a flat track ‚Äì you need to find a way to attack even with no help from the conditions. And another of looking at things might be that the good bowlers look to attack on every wicket.

12.13pm BST

‚ÄúOn the subject of spreading joy,‚Äù emails Brian Withington, ‚Äúall three seasons of the Detectorists are a delight but the last episode is simply wonderful. See also Marvellous, also with the impeccably life-affirming Toby Jones lead role. You‚Äôre welcome.‚Äù

Someone pressed the Detectorists on me quite some time ago, and I sort of mentally filed it under whimsy. But if it‚Äôs worth a go, will have a look ‚Äì and agree on Marvellous.

12.10pm BST

Ian Ward reckons rain until about 2pm, then we should get a decent amount of cricket thereafter. ‚ÄúFrom his mouth to God‚Äôs ears,‚Äù as my Gran would‚Äôve said.

12.06pm BST

‚ÄúG‚Äôday Daniel,‚Äù says Alistair Connor. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thinking ‚ÄòHa. England. Summer. Rain.‚Äô But to be honest, you‚Äôve got just as much of a chance of rain interruption in Auckland in December. Except that the rain is warmer. And it doesn‚Äôt last all bloody day.‚Äù

What‚Äôs especially galling here is that in most of the country, they‚Äôre playing ‚Äì even Old Trafford, for crying out loud. But hopefully we‚Äôll get enough in today to make the next two days what they should be.

12.02pm BST

In other what were you doing at 16 affirmation:

I‚Äôm sure that when he‚Äôs not in the middle, he‚Äôs memorising every lyric and noise of Dummy.

11.58am BST

Oh, and one more: Musa Okwonga‚Äôs book, One of Them, achieves the difficult feat of being an easy read ‚Äì it‚Äôs propulsive and entertaining ‚Äì and a difficult read ‚Äì it teaches you things about the world and about yourself that are upsetting. Find out more:

Related: Musa Okwonga: ‚ÄòBoys don‚Äôt learn shamelessness at Eton, it is where they perfect it‚Äô

11.52am BST

Longtime members of our community will know that the OBO is not just for cricket but for the general sharing of joy, so allow me to recommend a couple of things that have enriched my recent life: Les Mis√©rables ‚Äì not the original, but the Ladj Li film on Netflix ‚Äì is really, really worth your heart and mind. And, on an entirely different tip, American Barbecue Showdown has perhaps the most likeable cast of any reality show I‚Äôve seen.

11.46am BST

Yeah, it‚Äôs still raining. No one has sent me any cake to stimulate conversation but we can pretend to the contrary; I‚Äôd love a school dinner-style treacle sponge.

11.44am BST

It‚Äôs interesting that Chris Silverwood has asked for flatter pitches this summer, so his bowlers get better at finding a way and his batsmen get better at occupying the crease. I guess we can add it to the IPL on our list of things about which KP was right, but otherwise that strikes me as good news for Jofra Archer and Mark Wood, whose pace becomes even more valuable. I also can‚Äôt wait to see how Branderson impose themselves just when we think that conditions are against them.

fields.body:
3.36pm BST

FBI chief likens recent ransomware attacks to 9/11 challenge

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, Christopher Wray, the director of the FBI, compared the recent spate of ransomware attacks to the September 11, 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center.

Here‚Äôs his comments in the Journal:

FBI Director Christopher Wray said the agency is investigating about 100 different types of ransomware, many of which trace back to hackers in Russia, and compared the current spate of cyberattacks with the challenge posed by the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

‚ÄúThere are a lot of parallels, there‚Äôs a lot of importance, and a lot of focus by us on disruption and prevention,‚Äù Mr. Wray said in an interview on Thursday. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a shared responsibility, not just across government agencies but across the private sector and even the average American.‚Äù

Mr. Wray‚Äôs comments‚Äîamong his first publicly since two recent ransomware attacks gripped the U.S. meat and oil-and-gas industries‚Äîcome as senior Biden administration officials have characterized ransomware as an urgent national-security threat and said they are looking at ways to disrupt the criminal ecosystem that supports the booming industry. Each of the 100 different malicious software variants are responsible for multiple ransomware attacks in the U.S., Mr. Wray said.

Cyberattacks are something the president plans to bring up when he meets with Russian president Vladimir Putin. Earlier this week Biden told reporters that his administration is looking ‚Äúclosely‚Äù at possibly retaliating against Russia over ransomware attacks.

‚ÄúResponsible states do not harbor ransomware criminals,‚Äù White House press secretary Jen Psaki said recently.

Updated at 3.50pm BST

3.14pm BST

The Texas Tribune throws out the possibility that Allen West could be gearing up to challenge incumbent governor Greg Abbott, a Republican. Here‚Äôs the Tribune:

West has not ruled out challenging Gov. Greg Abbott, and he has also had tension recently with Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick.

A former Florida congressman who moved to Texas several years ago, West took over the party last summer, unseating incumbent James Dickey. He quickly made a name for himself for his willingness to speak out against fellow Republicans, including Abbott, whose coronavirus response he criticized.

West used the latest legislative session to push hard for the party‚Äôs eight legislative priorities, and he has spent recent days lamenting the lack of progress that lawmakers have to show on them.

It‚Äôs important to note that Abbott is a popular politician in Texas and has recently touted Donald Trump‚Äôs endorsement. He also won his last gubernatorial election by 13 percentage points. Unseating Abbott would not be easy.

2.41pm BST

The jobs report numbers out today were overall positive. My colleague Dominic Rushe has more:

The US added 559,000 jobs in May as the coronavirus pandemic receded, shaking off fears of a substantial slowdown in hiring after April‚Äôs disappointing monthly report.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics said Friday that the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.8% from 6.1% in April, still significantly higher than the 3.8% unemployment rate recorded in February 2020 before Covid 19 hit the US but less than half its 14.8% peak in April last year.

The news comes one month after the labor department shocked economists by announcing the US had added just 266,000 new jobs in April ‚Äì far below the 1m gain that had been expected.

April‚Äôs report led to sparring between the Biden administration and Republicans who claimed higher levels of unemployment benefits were keeping people from returning to work.

There are signs of a strong rebound across the US economy. Worker filings for unemployment benefits have dropped by 35% since late April and fell to a pandemic low of 385,000 last week, the labor department said Thursday.

Related: US adds 559,000 jobs in May as fears of hiring slowdown fade

2.27pm BST

Former congressman Allen West, the ex-Florida member of Congress-turned chairman of the Texas Republican Party, is stepping down from his post.

He had been leading the Texas Republican Party for less than a year, a short tenure for a chairman to abruptly end.

There seems to be some confusion about the timing of when his departure will go into effect. While the vice chair of the party tweeted that West is stepping down at 5pm. today the party‚Äôs communications director tweeted that West will keep his job until early July.

Here‚Äôs a press release announcing West‚Äôs departure.

Updated at 2.32pm BST

2.15pm BST

Good morning readers, Daniel Strauss here. Let‚Äôs get started.

Joe Biden continues to find a deal with Republicans and conservative members of the Democratic party elusive on the primary legislative initiative his administration is focusing on.

Later today, Biden is meeting with Senator Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia. It‚Äôs the latest meeting between the president and the lead Republican negotiator over a major infrastructure funding package.

Despite repeated counter offers by Capito and her team of Senate Republicans, the White House and Congress have not gotten close to a compromise. And that‚Äôs caused Biden and his top aides to warn that time is running out to come up with a bipartisan deal.

But there are persistent fissures within the Democratic Party as well. In an interview with CNN, Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia, the most conservative Democrat in the Senate caucus and the most outspoken conservative Democrat on Capitol Hill, warned that he‚Äôs not ready to give up on a bipartisan compromise. Per CNN:

In an interview with CNN on Thursday, Manchin said bipartisan infrastructure talks should continue even as pressure builds for Democrats to move ahead without Republicans, and he dismissed calls to create a special carveout from the Senate‚Äôs filibuster rules to pass a voting overhaul bill along straight party lines, a key priority for Democrats that faces stiff opposition from GOP lawmakers.

Manchin heads into a pivotal time for Congress where a number of key policy issues are on a razor‚Äôs edge in the Senate, giving the swing Democrat enormous sway over the future of the Biden agenda. At the centerpiece of that agenda is the infrastructure package that Biden and Republicans are furiously negotiating in a last-ditch attempt to cut a compromise, though they remain far apart.

The West Virginia Democrat is not ready to give up on those talks with Republicans quite yet, saying: ‚ÄúThese (things) take time.‚Äù

Manchin‚Äôs comments underscore one of the more persistent aspects of Congressional gridlock that‚Äôs continued through the Biden administration: a small, moderate sect of the Democratic Party opposes the drastic go-it-alone approach other wings of the party are pushing for on a range of issues ‚Äì from filibuster reform in the Senate to an infrastructure deal.

results.webTitle: EU bans Belarus planes from its airspace over blogger arrest

fields.headline: EU bans Belarus planes from its airspace over blogger arrest
fields.standfirst: Move follows forced landing of Ryanair flight and detention of Raman Pratasevich last month
fields.trailText: Move follows forced landing of Ryanair flight and detention of Raman Pratasevich last month
fields.body:
The EU has banned Belarusian carriers from its airspace and airports over the forced landing of Ryanair flight FR4978 and arrest of the opposition blogger Raman Pratasevich.

EU ambassadors agreed during a meeting on Friday to require member states to deny the country‚Äôs carriers landing and taking off rights and forbid them from overflying the territory of the 27 member states from Saturday.

The European aviation safety agency (EASA) has also issued a directive which effectively bans EU aircraft from flying over Belarusian airspace or landing on its territory.

The twin move follows last month‚Äôs denunciation by EU heads of state and government of the interception of the Athens-to-Vilnius flight on 23 May on which Pratasevich and his Russian girlfriend Sofia Sapega were passengers.

There is growing concern over Pratasevich‚Äôs health after appearances on video in which he exhibited signs of abuse while apparently confessing to crimes against the Belarusian state.

Willy Walsh, the former chief executive of the owners of British Airways and now director general of the International Air Transport Association (Iata), said he was concerned about the politicisation of air travel.

‚ÄúBanning European aircraft from using Belarusian airspace with a safety directive is also a politicisation of aviation safety,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is a retrograde and disappointing development. EASA should rescind its prohibition and allow airlines to manage safety as they do each and every day, with their normal operational risk assessments.

Related: Raman Pratasevich: the Belarus journalist captured by a fighter jet

‚ÄúTwo wrongs do not make a right. Politics should never interfere with the safe operation of aircraft and politicians should never use aviation safety as a cover to pursue political or diplomatic agendas.‚Äù

Under other measures the EU leaders agreed last month, a range of economic sanctions will be applied against those involved in the incident. European diplomats are expected to finalise the list of officials and entities to be targeted next week,

They are also drawing up proposals for broader economic sanctions, which could come into force later in the month and include the country‚Äôs fertiliser industry and its sale of bonds.

The EU imposed sanctions on nearly 60 Belarusian officials last year, including the country‚Äôs president Alexander Lukashenko and his son Victor, after the crackdown on peaceful protests against last August‚Äôs allegedly rigged presidential election result.

fields.standfirst: With most late-night hosts on vacation, Jimmy Kimmel discusses herd immunity in Los Angeles, Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs fundraiser and Jill Biden‚Äôs 70th birthday
fields.trailText: With most late-night hosts on vacation, Jimmy Kimmel discusses herd immunity in Los Angeles, Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs fundraiser and Jill Biden‚Äôs 70th birthday
fields.body:
Jimmy Kimmel

With most late-night hosts still on holiday until next week, Jimmy Kimmel looked ahead to potential herd immunity for coronavirus in his home base of Los Angeles. Earlier in the week, Los Angeles county officials revised their predicted timeline for the milestone from July to late August due to falling vaccination rates. ‚ÄúInstead of vaccine I think we should start calling it arm botox,‚Äù Kimmel joked.

‚ÄúThe most frustrating thing is that a lot of these unvaccinated people aren‚Äôt just avoiding getting the shot; they‚Äôre not getting masks,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòPandemic‚Äôs over!‚Äô Not for you it isn‚Äôt! Listen, you didn‚Äôt chip in for the gift, you don‚Äôt get to sign the card.‚Äù

Meanwhile, ‚Äúalmost everything is as it was in New York, including state politics‚Äù, Kimmel continued, pointing to a lavish fundraiser planned by the embattled governor, Andrew Cuomo, for later this month, the first since multiple scandals from sexual harassment, accusations of bullying and a cover-up of Covid nursing home deaths engulfed his administration.

Related: Jimmy Kimmel on Trump abandoning his blog: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a move he calls the Eric‚Äô

The fundraiser is the latest indication that Cuomo intends to run for a fourth term as governor, even as members of his own party in Albany demanded his resignation. It will cost $10,000 a person, or $15,000 for two people, to attend. ‚ÄúTen thousand dollars a plate, and for an extra $250 he‚Äôll whisper something in your ear that will haunt you for decades,‚Äù Kimmel joked.

The fundraiser, billed in an email to campaign donors as a ‚Äúsummer reception‚Äù, will take place 29 June at an undisclosed location in New York City ‚Äì ‚Äúwhich is exactly what you want to hear from a guy facing multiple sexual harassment accusations‚Äù, Kimmel deadpanned.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs basically his version of OnlyFans now, this thing.‚Äù

And finally, Kimmel celebrated Jill Biden‚Äôs 70th birthday. ‚ÄúThe president and his bride celebrated by going to their beach house in Delaware ‚Äì which is I guess the most old person thing Joe could think of,‚Äù Kimmel joked. ‚ÄúThey watched the sun set over the novelty T-shirt shops and adult video stores.‚Äù
